senses.definition: to show that something is possible or likely as a solution, an explanation, etc.
if you say that something is a foregone conclusion, you mean that it is a result that is certain to happen a foregone conclusion

examples.x: The outcome of the vote is a foregone conclusion.
The result of the game was a foregone conclusion.

senses.definition: an arrangement to risk money, etc. on the result of a particular event; the money that you risk in this way

examples.x: to win/lose a bet
I was tempted to place a large bet.
We've got a bet on who's going to arrive first.
He had a bet on the horses.
They all put a bet on the race.
I hear you're taking bets on whether she'll marry him.
I did it for a bet (= because somebody had agreed to pay me money if I did).
‘Liverpool are bound to win.’ ‘Do you want a bet?’ (= I disagree with you, I don't think they will.)

senses.definition: an opinion about what is likely to happen or to have happened

examples.x: My bet is that they've been held up in traffic.

senses.definition: measuring or covering a great length or distance, or a greater length or distance than usual

examples.x: She had long dark hair.
He walked down the long corridor.
It was the world's longest bridge.
a long journey/walk/drive/flight
We're a long way from anywhere here.
It's a long way away.
He had long, thin fingers.
a lush meadow of long grass

senses.definition: used for asking or talking about particular lengths or distances

examples.x: How long is the River Nile?
The table is six feet long.
The report is only three pages long.

senses.definition: lasting or taking a great amount of time or more time than usual (for) long

examples.x: He’s been ill (for) a long time.
There was a long silence before she spoke.
I like it now the days are getting longer (= it stays light for more time each day).
a long book/film/list (= taking a lot of time to read/watch/deal with)
Nurses have to work long hours (= for more hours in the day than is usual).
He stared at them for the longest time (= for a very long time) before answering.
Chicago has a long history of country music.
to have a long life/career

senses.definition: used for asking or talking about particular periods of time

examples.x: How long is the course?
I think it's only three weeks long.
How long a stay did you have in mind?

senses.definition: seeming to last or take more time than it really does because, for example, you are very busy or not happy

examples.x: I'm tired. It's been a long day.
We were married for ten long years.

senses.definition: covering all or most of your legs or arms

examples.x: She usually wears long skirts.
a long-sleeved shirt

senses.definition: travelling a great distance

examples.x: The full-back intercepted an attempted long pass and ran through to score.
A hopeful long ball from out of defence led to a goal.
She's good with the driver and hits a long ball.

senses.definition: travelling too far so that it goes out of play

examples.x: Her return of serve was long.

senses.definition: having a lot of a particular quality

examples.x: The government is long on ideas but short on performance.

senses.definition: a long vowel is pronounced for a longer time than other vowels long

examples.x: Compare the long vowel in ‘beat’ and the short vowel in ‘bit’.

senses.definition: an action or an opinion that is not correct, or that produces a result that you did not want

examples.x: It's easy to make a mistake.
Don't worry, we all make mistakes.
You are making a big mistake.
Leaving school so young was the biggest mistake of my life.
a terrible/serious/huge mistake
It’s a common mistake (= one that a lot of people make).
You must try to learn from your mistakes.
He is determined not to repeat the mistakes of his predecessors.
This letter is addressed to someone else—there must be some mistake.
I made the mistake of giving him my address.

examples.cf: it is a mistake to do something
examples.x: It would be a mistake to ignore his opinion.
It was a big mistake on my part to have trusted her.

senses.definition: a word, figure, etc. that is not said or written down correctly mistake

examples.x: It's a common mistake among learners of English.
Her essay is full of spelling mistakes.
If students correct their own mistakes, learning improves.
The waiter made a mistake (in) adding up the bill.

senses.definition: having had the kind of education mentioned; having been to the school, college or university mentioned

examples.x: privately educated children
a British-educated lawyer
He's a Princeton-educated Texan.
They were poorly educated and spoke little English.

senses.definition: having had a high standard of education; showing a high standard of education

examples.x: He seemed intelligent and well educated.
a highly educated workforce
Less educated people are missing out on these opportunities.
This is sometimes seen as the newspaper for an educated elite.
She's an educated and articulate spokeswoman.
He spoke in an educated voice.

senses.definition: an attempt to give an answer or an opinion when you cannot be certain if you are right get

examples.x: to have/make a guess
to take a guess
Go on! Have a guess!
If I might hazard a guess, I'd say she was about thirty.
Who do you think I saw yesterday? I'll give you three guesses.
They might be here by 3—but that's just a rough guess (= not exact).
But this is clearly just a wild guess (= not sensible or accurate) at what his motives could have been.
The article is based on guesses about what might happen in the future.
the market's best guess as to the possible performance of the company
My guess is that we won't hear from him again.
At a guess, there were forty people at the party.

senses.definition: well known, but probably not true Apocryphal

examples.x: Most of the stories about him are apocryphal.

senses.definition: using facts or principles that are known to be true in order to decide what the likely effects or results of something will be, for example saying ‘They haven’t eaten anything all day so they must be hungry.’

examples.x: an a priori assumption

senses.definition: the mark ( ? ) used in writing after a question
that you can give good reasons for

examples.x: He had a good arguable case.
It is arguable that giving too much detail may actually be confusing.

senses.definition: not certain; that you do not accept without question

examples.x: It is arguable whether the case should ever have gone to trial (= perhaps it should not have).

senses.definition: a long distance away a long way

examples.x: We didn't go far.
Have you come far?
It's not far to the beach.
There's not far to go now.
It's too far to walk.
The restaurant is not far from here.
countries as far apart as Japan and Brazil
He looked down at the traffic far below.
Far away in the distance, a train whistled.
The farther north they went, the colder it became.
a concert of music from near and far
Legends are usually far removed from the reality.

senses.definition: used when you are asking or talking about the distance between two places or the distance that has been travelled or is to be travelled

examples.x: How far is it to your house from here?
How far is Boston from New York?
How much further is it?
I'm not sure I can walk so far.
We'll go by train as far as London, and then take a bus.
We didn't go as far as the others.

senses.definition: a long time from the present; for a large part of a particular period of time

examples.x: The band had their first hit as far back as 2012.
To answer that question we need to go further back in time.
Let's try to plan further ahead.
We worked far into the night.
The film takes place in a future not too far distant.

senses.definition: very much; to a great degree

examples.x: That's a far better idea.
The damage was far worse than I'd expected.
a drug that gives heart attack victims a far greater chance of survival
There are far more opportunities for young people than there used to be.
She always gives us far too much homework.
The results far exceeded my expectations.
The benefits far outweigh the cost.
The recent heat and continued drought further reduced yields.
It had been a success far beyond their expectations.
He's fallen far behind in his work.

senses.definition: used when you are asking or talking about the degree to which something is true or possible

examples.x: How far can we trust him?
His parents supported him as far as they could.

senses.definition: used to talk about how much progress has been made in doing or achieving something

examples.x: How far have you got with that report?
Half an hour later Duncan was no farther in his quest.
I read as far as the third chapter.
We’ve got as far as collecting our data but we haven’t analysed it yet.

senses.definition: the lack of light in a place, especially because it is night

examples.x: Are the children afraid of the dark?
All the lights went out and we were left in the dark.
animals that can see in the dark

senses.definition: an amount of something that is dark in colour

examples.x: patterns of light and dark

senses.definition: used in very informal speech, for example when you are thinking what to say next, explaining something, or giving an example of something

examples.x: It was, like, weird.
It was kind of scary, like.
It's really hard. Like I have no time for my own work.

senses.definition: used in very informal speech to show that what you are saying may not be exactly right but is nearly so

examples.x: I'm leaving in like twenty minutes.
It's going to cost like a hundred dollars.

senses.definition: used in very informal speech, to mean ‘I say’, ‘he/she says’, etc.

examples.x: And then I'm like ‘No Way!’

senses.definition: used in informal speech instead of as to say that something happens in the same way as

examples.x: There was silence, but not like before.

senses.definition: very probably likely

examples.x: As likely as not she's forgotten all about it.
The illness was caused, most likely, by a virus.

senses.definition: to tell somebody that something is definitely true or is definitely going to happen, especially when they have doubts about it

examples.x: You think I did it deliberately, but I assure you (that) I did not.
Let me assure you that I will try to help you.
We were assured that everything possible was being done.
She's perfectly safe, I can assure you.
We assured him of our support.
I won’t let you down, I can assure you of that.
‘He'll come back,’ Susan assured her.

senses.definition: to make yourself certain about something

examples.x: He assured himself of her safety.
She assured herself that the letter was still in the drawer.

senses.definition: to make something certain to happen

examples.x: Victory would assure a place in the finals.
Victory would assure them a place in the finals.
This achievement has assured her a place in the history books.

senses.definition: to insure something, especially against somebody’s death

examples.x: What is the sum assured?

senses.definition: confident in yourself and your abilities

examples.x: He spoke in a calm, assured voice.

senses.definition: certain to happen

examples.x: Success seemed assured.

senses.definition: certain to get something

examples.x: You are assured of a warm welcome at this hotel.

senses.definition: a written or printed symbol that is used as a sign of something, for example the quality of something or who made or owns it

examples.x: I put a mark in the margin to remind me to check the figure.
Any piece of silver bearing his mark is extremely valuable.
A faint pencil mark showed where the house was on the map.
Every image is made up of hundreds of brush marks.

senses.definition: a number or letter that is given to show the standard of somebody’s work or performance or is given to somebody for answering something correctly

examples.x: to get a good/poor mark in English
to give somebody a high/low mark

senses.definition: a point given for a correct answer in an exam or competition

examples.x: You get two marks for each correct answer.

I got full marks (= all the possible points) in the spelling test.
‘You're wearing a tie!’ ‘Full marks for observation.’

senses.definition: a small area of dirt, a spot or a cut on a surface that makes it look less good mark

examples.x: The children left dirty marks all over the kitchen floor.
There was a red mark on his arm.
a burn/scratch mark
Detectives found no marks on the body.

senses.definition: a spot or area of colour on the body of a person or an animal that helps you to recognize them patch

examples.x: a horse with a white mark on its head
He was about six feet tall, with no distinguishing marks.
Look for a bird with a blue mark on its wings.

senses.definition: a sign that a quality or feeling exists

examples.x: On the day of the funeral businesses remained closed as a mark of respect.

senses.definition: a level or point that something reaches that is thought to be important

examples.x: Unemployment has passed the four million mark.

The needle was flickering around the 80 mark.
She was leading at the halfway mark.

senses.definition: a particular type or model of a machine or vehicle

examples.x: the Mark II engine

senses.definition: a particular level of temperature in a gas oven

examples.x: Preheat the oven to gas Mark 6.

senses.definition: a cross made on a document instead of a signature by somebody who is not able to write their name
a target

examples.x: Of the blows delivered, barely half found their mark.
to hit/miss the mark
Shock tactics often fall wide of their mark (= are not successful).

senses.definition: the former unit of money in Germany (replaced in 2002 by the euro)
to promise to do something; to promise something will happen

examples.x: Basic human rights, including freedom of speech, are now guaranteed.

senses.definition: to give a written promise to replace or repair a product free if it goes wrong

examples.x: All our electrical goods are fully guaranteed.

senses.definition: to make something certain to happen

senses.definition: to be certain that something will happen

examples.x: You can guarantee (that) the children will start being naughty as soon as they have to go to bed.

senses.definition: to agree to be legally responsible for something or for doing something, especially for paying back money that somebody else owes if they cannot pay it back themselves

examples.x: to guarantee a bank loan

senses.definition: a container made of cloth, leather, plastic or paper, used to carry things in, especially when shopping or travelling

examples.x: He was carrying a heavy bag of groceries.

a make-up bag
a baby changing bag

senses.definition: a bag or case that you take when you are travelling; a piece of luggage

examples.x: I packed my bags and left for the airport.

senses.definition: the amount contained in a bag

examples.x: She ate a bag of chips.

senses.definition: a large amount or a large number of something

examples.x: Get in! There's bags of room.

senses.definition: dark circles or loose folds of skin under the eyes, as a result of getting old or lack of sleep
an offensive word for an older woman who you think is unpleasant or angry
all the birds, animals, etc. shot or caught on one occasion

examples.x: We got a good bag today.

senses.definition: a possibility of something happening, especially something that you want

examples.x: She only has a slim chance of passing the exam.

senses.definition: a suitable time or situation when you have the opportunity to do something

senses.definition: to have the opinion that something is right or true according to

examples.x: She couldn’t believe (that) it was all happening again.

senses.definition: to have a religious faith

examples.x: The god appears only to those who believe.

senses.definition: to feel certain that somebody/something exists

There was a red mark on his arm.
a burn/scratch mark

examples.x: a horse with a white mark on its head

senses.definition: a sign that a quality or feeling exists

examples.x: On the day of the funeral businesses remained closed as a mark of respect.

senses.definition: a level or point that something reaches that is thought to be important

examples.x: Unemployment has passed the four million mark.

senses.definition: a particular type or model of a machine or vehicle

senses.definition: a particular level of temperature in a gas oven

examples.x: Preheat the oven to gas Mark 6.

senses.definition: a cross made on a document instead of a signature by somebody who is not able to write their name
a target

examples.x: Of the blows delivered, barely half found their mark.
to hit/miss the mark
Shock tactics often fall wide of their mark (= are not successful).

senses.definition: the former unit of money in Germany (replaced in 2002 by the euro)
used to describe something that you have failed to see, even though it was obvious and should have been easy to see

examples.x: The answer was staring us in the face but we never saw it until it was too late.

senses.definition: to be certain to happen

examples.x: Defeat was staring them in the face.

senses.definition: to risk money on a race or an event by trying to predict the result

examples.x: You have to be over 16 to bet.

senses.definition: cheerful and feeling sure that things will be successful

senses.definition: used to express doubt or surprise

senses.definition: used to say that somebody must do something, usually when you are angry modal verbs

senses.definition: made of cast iron

senses.definition: very strong or certain; that cannot be broken or fail

examples.x: the English and their inevitable cups of tea

senses.definition: something that is certain to happen

examples.x: You have to accept the inevitable.

senses.definition: as is certain to happen

examples.x: Inevitably, the press exaggerated the story.

senses.definition: as you would expect

examples.x: Inevitably, it rained on the day of the wedding.

senses.definition: near the beginning of a period of time, an event etc.

examples.x: the early morning
my earliest memories

the early 1990s
in the early years of the twentieth century
in the early days of space exploration (= when it was just beginning)

examples.cf: it is too early to do something

senses.definition: arriving, or done before the usual, expected or planned time

an early breakfast

early potatoes (= that are available before other types of potato)

What's the matter with you today (= why are you behaving like this)?

senses.definition: a subject or situation that you must consider or deal with

examples.x: It's a private matter.

financial/legal/political matters

It's a matter for the police (= for them to deal with).
It was a matter of some concern to most of those present (= something they were worried about).

It was no easy matter getting him to change his mind.
Let's get on with the matter in hand (= what we need to deal with now).

I did not feel that we had got to the heart of the matter (= the most important part).
And that is the crux of the matter (= the most important thing about the situation).

senses.definition: the present situation, or the situation that you are talking about

examples.x: Unfortunately, there is nothing we can do to improve matters.

I decided to take matters into my own hands (= deal with the situation myself).
Matters came to a head (= the situation became very difficult) with his resignation.

senses.definition: a situation that involves something or depends on something

examples.x: Learning to drive is all a matter of coordination.

The government must deal with this as a matter of urgency.
Just as a matter of interest (= because it is interesting, not because it is important), how much did you pay for it?
‘I think this is the best so far.’ ‘Well, that's a matter of opinion (= other people may think differently).’

Getting the effect you want is a matter of trial and error.

Planning a project is just a matter of working out the right order to do things in.

senses.definition: physical substance that everything in the world is made of; not mind or spirit

examples.x: to study the properties of matter

senses.definition: a substance or things of a particular sort

examples.x: Add plenty of organic matter to improve the soil.
elimination of waste matter from the body

There were small lumps of matter floating on the surface.

senses.definition: certain or likely to happen, or to do or be something certain

examples.x: There are bound to be changes when the new system is introduced.

senses.definition: forced to do something by law, duty or a particular situation

senses.definition: prevented from going somewhere or from working normally by the conditions mentioned

examples.x: Strike-bound travellers face long delays.
fogbound airports

senses.definition: travelling, or ready to travel, in a particular direction or to a particular place

examples.x: homeward bound (= going home)
Paris-bound
northbound/southbound/eastbound/westbound
a plane bound for Dublin
tourists who are bound for Europe
college-bound high school students

senses.definition: to form an opinion about somebody/something, based on the information you have

examples.x: As far as I can judge, all of them are to blame.

You shouldn't judge her too harshly.

Each painting must be judged on its own merits.
The tour was judged a great success.
The concert was judged to have been a great success.

He judged that the risk was too great.
It was judged that the risk was too great.

senses.definition: to guess the size, amount, etc. of something

examples.x: Young children are unable to judge the speed of traffic.

senses.definition: to decide the result of a competition; to be the judge in a competition

examples.x: She was asked to judge the essay competition.

senses.definition: to give your opinion about somebody, especially when you think they are bad

examples.x: What gives you the right to judge other people?

senses.definition: to decide whether somebody is guilty or innocent in a court

examples.x: to judge a case
to judge somebody guilty/not guilty

examples.x: No one knows the answer.

‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’

‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)
‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).

I knew where he was hiding.
No one knows for sure who did it.
You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?
I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.
I know next to nothing (= know almost nothing) about opera.
I know of someone who can help us.
‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’
Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?
We know her to be honest.
Strobe lights are known to cause seizures.

senses.definition: to realize, understand or be aware of something

examples.x: As soon as I walked in the room I knew (that) something was wrong.

‘Martin was lying all the time.’ ‘I should have known.’

I know exactly how you feel.

senses.definition: to feel certain about something knew

examples.x: He knew (that) he could trust her.

I don't know that I can finish it by next week.

‘You were right—someone's been spreading rumours about you.’ ‘I knew it!’
‘She's the worst player in the team.’ ‘Oh, I don't know (= I am not sure that I agree)—she played well yesterday.’

senses.definition: to be familiar with a person, place, thing, etc.

examples.x: I've known David for 20 years.

I know Paris well.
Do you know the play (= have you seen or read it before)?

senses.definition: to have learned a skill or language and be able to use it

examples.x: Do you know any Japanese?

senses.definition: to think that somebody/something is a particular type of person or thing or has particular characteristics

senses.definition: to give somebody/something a particular name or title

examples.cf: be known as somebody/something to somebody

senses.definition: to be able to recognize somebody/something identify

examples.x: I couldn't see who was speaking, but I knew the voice.

senses.definition: to understand the difference between one person or thing and another

senses.definition: to have seen, heard or experienced something

examples.x: I’ve never known it (to) snow in July before.

senses.definition: to have personal experience of something

examples.x: He has known both poverty and wealth.

senses.definition: to give something to somebody or allow them to use something that belongs to you, which they have to return to you later borrow

examples.x: They will lend equipment free of charge.

senses.definition: to give money to somebody on condition that they pay it back over a period of time and pay interest on it

examples.x: The bank lends money at very cheap rates.

senses.definition: to give a particular quality to a person or a situation

examples.x: The setting sun lent an air of melancholy to the scene.

senses.definition: to give or provide help, support, etc.

examples.x: I was more than happy to lend my support to such a good cause.

senses.definition: a fine powder that consists of very small pieces of sand, earth, etc.

examples.x: A cloud of dust rose as the truck drove off.

senses.definition: the fine powder of dirt that forms in buildings, on furniture, floors, etc.

examples.x: The books were all covered with dust.
There was a thick layer of dust on the table.
There wasn't a speck of dust anywhere in the room.
She is allergic to house dust.

senses.definition: a fine powder that consists of very small pieces of a particular substance

examples.x: coal dust

senses.definition: having a good chance of happening or being something; probable or expected By

examples.x: the most likely explanation/outcome/scenario
the likely cause/consequence
a likely nominee/contender/winner

senses.definition: seeming suitable for a purpose

senses.definition: to turn your eyes in a particular direction look

senses.definition: to try to find somebody/something

examples.x: Where have you been? We've been looking for you.

senses.definition: to pay attention to something

senses.definition: to seem; to appear

examples.x: How do I look?

senses.definition: to face a particular direction

senses.definition: strongly believing something; having no doubts

examples.x: I think it was him, but I can't be certain.

senses.definition: that you can rely on to happen or to be true certain

not exactly/entirely/absolutely/really sure

senses.definition: certain that you will receive something or that something will happen sure

senses.definition: certain to do something or to happen certain

senses.definition: that can be trusted or relied on certain

senses.definition: steady and confident

senses.definition: used to make a polite suggestion

senses.definition: used to ask permission politely

examples.x: Might I use your phone?

senses.definition: used to ask for information

examples.x: How might the plans be improved upon?

senses.definition: used to show that you are annoyed about something that somebody could do or could have done

senses.definition: used to say that you are not surprised by something

senses.definition: used to emphasize that an important point has been made modal verbs

senses.definition: certain or definite

senses.definition: (in betting) believed to be very likely to succeed

senses.definition: used when you are saying that something is likely

examples.x: No doubt she'll call us when she gets there.

senses.definition: used when you are saying that something is certainly true

examples.x: He's made some great movies. There's no doubt about it.

senses.definition: based on a guess, estimate or theory; not existing in reality

senses.definition: used to say that something cannot be avoided Necessarily

examples.x: The number of places available is necessarily limited.

senses.definition: the highest part or point of something

examples.x: She was standing at the top of the stairs.

the top of the milk (= the cream that rises to the top of a bottle of milk)

senses.definition: the upper flat surface of something

senses.definition: a piece of clothing worn on the upper part of the body

a tracksuit/bikini/pyjama top

senses.definition: a thing that you put on the end of something to close it lid

examples.x: Where's the top of this pen?
a bottle with a screw top

senses.definition: the highest or most important rank or position

examples.x: They finished the season at the top of the league.

senses.definition: the leaves of a plant that is grown mainly for its root

senses.definition: a child’s toy that turns round on a point when it is moved very quickly by hand or by a string

examples.x: She was so confused—her mind was spinning like a top.

senses.definition: a detailed description of something, especially the design and materials needed to produce something Spec

examples.x: We want the machine manufactured to our own spec.

senses.definition: used to introduce another possibility or

examples.x: Is your sister older or younger than you?
Are you coming or not?
Is it a boy or a girl?

senses.definition: used in negative sentences when mentioning two or more things

examples.x: He can't read or write.

senses.definition: used to warn or advise somebody that something bad could happen; otherwise

examples.x: Turn the heat down or it'll burn.

senses.definition: used between two numbers to show approximately how many

examples.x: There were six or seven of us there.

senses.definition: used to introduce a word or phrase that explains or means the same as another

senses.definition: used to say why something must be true

examples.x: He must like her, or he wouldn't keep calling her.

senses.definition: used to introduce a different or opposite idea

examples.x: He was lying—or was he?

senses.definition: used in questions to ask for particular information about somebody/something

examples.x: What is your name?

What time is it?
What kind of music do you like?

senses.definition: the thing or things that; whatever

senses.definition: used to say that you think that something is especially good, bad, etc.

senses.definition: used to say what is the right thing to do ought

senses.definition: used to say what you advise or recommend

examples.x: Travel broadens your outlook.
a/an positive/optimistic outlook
a bleak/gloomy/pessimistic outlook

senses.definition: the likely future for somebody/something; what is likely to happen

examples.cf: unsure as to how, what, etc…
examples.x: They were unsure as to what the next move should be.

senses.definition: not having enough confidence in yourself

examples.x: Like many women, deep down she was unsure of herself.

senses.definition: at a fairly high temperature in a way that is pleasant, rather than being hot or cold

examples.x: warm weather/temperatures/air
Wash the blouse in warm soapy water.
Tomorrow will be warm and sunny.
a warm and dry spell
Are you warm enough?
The children jumped up and down to keep warm.
I can’t seem to get warm.
Wait for the warmer weather before putting the plants in the garden.
a warm climate
It's nice and warm in here.
Heat the bread until it is warm to the touch.
The sun felt warm on his skin.

senses.definition: keeping you warm or staying warm in cold weather

examples.x: warm clothing/clothes
a warm pair of socks
This sleeping bag is very warm.
I wish I had a warm house to go back to.

senses.definition: showing enthusiasm, friendship or love

examples.x: Her smile was warm and friendly.
The star received a warm welcome from fans.
The speaker was given a warm reception.
He felt a warm glow at the memory.
a warm smile/greeting
She threw her arms around me in a warm embrace.
Most people get a warm feeling when they see puppies playing together.
Please send her my warmest congratulations.
Her comments were greeted with warm applause.
an extremely warm and friendly person

senses.definition: containing red, orange or yellow, which creates a pleasant, comfortable and relaxed feeling or atmosphere

examples.x: The room was decorated in warm shades of red and orange.
Reds and yellows are warm colours that attract attention.

senses.definition: used to say that somebody has almost guessed the answer to something or that they have almost found somebody/something that has been hidden

examples.x: Keep guessing—you're getting warmer.

senses.definition: to make somebody/something less strong or powerful; to become less strong or powerful

examples.x: The team has been weakened by injury.
The new evidence weakens the case against her.
This new story has severely weakened the President’s position.
His authority is steadily weakening.

senses.definition: to make something less physically strong; to become less physically strong

examples.x: The explosion had weakened the building's foundations.
His health was weakened by overwork.
She felt her legs weaken.

senses.definition: to become or make somebody become less determined or certain about something

examples.x: You must not agree to do it. Don't weaken.
Nothing could weaken his resolve to continue.

senses.definition: to become less strong

examples.x: The storm eventually weakened.

senses.definition: to become less strong; to make a currency or economy less strong

examples.x: The dollar has weakened against the euro.
measures that could weaken the economy

senses.definition: in a good, right or acceptable way well

examples.x: They played well in the tournament.
The team work well together.
The kids all behaved well.
The conference was very well organized.
Well done! (= expressing admiration for what somebody has done)
His campaign was not going well.
These animals make very good pets if treated well (= with kindness).
People spoke well of (= spoke with approval of) him.
She took it very well (= did not react too badly), all things considered.
They lived well (= in comfort and spending a lot of money) and were generous with their money.
She was determined to marry well (= marry somebody rich and/or with a high social position).

senses.definition: completely and properly

examples.x: Add the lemon juice and mix well.
The surface must be well prepared before you start to paint.
How well do you know Carla?
He's well able to take care of himself.
a well trained dog

senses.definition: to a great extent or degree

examples.x: He was driving at well over the speed limit.
She is well aware of the dangers.
They are very well suited to each other.
a well-loved tale
The castle is well worth a visit.
He liked her well enough (= to a reasonable degree) but he wasn't going to make a close friend of her.
I was well annoyed, I can tell you.

senses.definition: easily

examples.x: She could well afford to pay for it herself.

senses.definition: probably

examples.x: You may well be right.
It may well be that the train is delayed.

senses.definition: with good reason

examples.x: I can't very well leave now.
I couldn't very well refuse to help them, could I?
‘What are we doing here?’ ‘You may well ask (= I don't really know either).’

senses.definition: used for talking about or predicting the future heal

examples.x: You'll be in time if you hurry.
How long will you be staying in Paris?
Fred said he'd be leaving soon.
By next year all the money will have been spent.

senses.definition: used for asking somebody to do something

examples.x: Will you send this letter for me, please?
You'll water the plants while I'm away, won't you?
I asked him if he wouldn't mind calling later.

senses.definition: used for inviting somebody to do something

examples.x: Will you join us for lunch?

senses.definition: used for showing that somebody is willing to do something

examples.x: I'll check this letter for you, if you want.
They won't lend us any more money.
He wouldn't come—he said he was too busy.
We said we would keep them.

senses.definition: used for ordering somebody to do something

examples.x: You'll do it this minute!
Will you be quiet!

senses.definition: used for stating what you think is probably true

examples.x: That'll be the doctor now.
You'll have had dinner already, I suppose.

senses.definition: used for stating what is generally true

examples.x: If it's made of wood it will float.
Engines won't run without lubricants.

senses.definition: used for stating what is true or possible in a particular case

examples.x: This jar will hold a kilo.
The door won't open!

senses.definition: used for talking about habits will

examples.x: She'll listen to music, alone in her room, for hours.
He would spend hours on the telephone.

senses.definition: used in questions with I for making offers or suggestions

examples.x: Will I call back later?

senses.definition: used when you are saying that something is likely

examples.x: No doubt she'll call us when she gets there.

senses.definition: used when you are saying that something is certainly true

examples.x: He's made some great movies. There's no doubt about it.

senses.definition: used in polite offers or invitations

examples.x: Would you like a sandwich?
Would you have dinner with me on Friday?

senses.definition: used to say what you like, love, hate, etc.

examples.cf: would like, love, hate, prefer, etc. something
examples.x: I'd love a coffee.

examples.cf: would like, etc. to do something
examples.x: I'd be only too glad to help.

examples.cf: would like, etc. somebody to do something
examples.x: I'd hate you to think I was criticizing you.
I'd rather come with you.
I'd rather you came with us.

senses.definition: used as the past form of will when reporting what somebody has said or thought

examples.x: He said he would be here at eight o'clock (= His words were: ‘I will be there at eight o'clock.’).
She asked if I would help.
They told me that they probably wouldn't come.

senses.definition: used for talking about the result of an event that you imagine

examples.x: She'd look better with shorter hair.
If you went to see him, he would be delighted.
Hurry up! It would be a shame to miss the beginning of the play.
She'd be a fool to accept it (= if she accepted).

senses.definition: used for describing a possible action or event that did not in fact happen, because something else did not happen first

examples.x: If I had seen the advertisement in time, I would have applied for the job.
They would never have met if she hadn't gone to Emma's party.

senses.definition: used for saying why somebody does something

examples.cf: so that somebody/something would do something
examples.x: She burned the letters so that her husband would never read them.

examples.cf: in order that somebody/something would do something
examples.x: He worked hard in order that he would pass all his exams.

senses.definition: used for saying what you want to happen

examples.x: I wish that you'd be quiet for a minute.

senses.definition: used to show that somebody/something was not willing or refused to do something

examples.x: She wouldn't change it, even though she knew it was wrong.
My car wouldn't start this morning.

senses.definition: used to ask somebody politely to do something

examples.x: Would you mind leaving us alone for a few minutes?
Would you open the door for me, please?

senses.definition: used to give opinions that you are not certain about

examples.x: I would imagine the job will take about two days.
I'd say he was about fifty.

senses.definition: used to give advice

examples.x: I wouldn't have any more to drink, if I were you.

senses.definition: used for talking about things that often happened in the past

examples.x: When my parents were away, my grandmother would take care of me.
He'd always be the first to offer to help.

senses.definition: used for talking about behaviour that you think is typical

examples.x: ‘She said it was your fault.’ ‘Well, she would say that, wouldn't she? She's never liked me.’

senses.definition: used to express a strong wish modal verbs

examples.x: Would that he had lived to see it.

senses.definition: to risk money on a race or an event by trying to predict the result

examples.x: You have to be over 16 to bet.
I wouldn't bet on them winning the next election.
Not many people are betting against France retaining their title.
He likes betting on horses and watching table tennis.
He bet $2 000 on the final score of the game.
You shouldn't praise a gambler for betting his life savings if he wins.
She bet me £20 (that) I wouldn't do it.
I bet her (that) the Democrats would not win.
He bet ten dollars (that) he could write a complete story in just six words.

senses.definition: used to say that you are almost certain that something is true or that something will happen

examples.x: I bet (that) we’re too late.
You can bet (that) the moment I sit down, the baby will wake up.
I'm willing to bet (that) the analysts will be wrong.
I’ll bet you (that) he knows all about it.

senses.definition: to risk money on a race or an event by trying to predict the result

examples.x: You have to be over 16 to bet.
I wouldn't bet on them winning the next election.
Not many people are betting against France retaining their title.
He likes betting on horses and watching table tennis.
He bet $2 000 on the final score of the game.
You shouldn't praise a gambler for betting his life savings if he wins.
She bet me £20 (that) I wouldn't do it.
I bet her (that) the Democrats would not win.
He bet ten dollars (that) he could write a complete story in just six words.

senses.definition: used to say that you are almost certain that something is true or that something will happen

examples.x: I bet (that) we’re too late.
You can bet (that) the moment I sit down, the baby will wake up.
I'm willing to bet (that) the analysts will be wrong.
I’ll bet you (that) he knows all about it.

senses.definition: the ability to breathe, grow, produce young, etc. that people, animals and plants have before they die and that objects do not have

examples.x: This could mean the difference between life and death.
The body was cold and showed no signs of life.
I wish we could bring dinosaurs back to life.
In spring the countryside bursts into life.

senses.definition: the state of being alive as a human; an individual person’s existence

examples.x: The floods caused a massive loss of life (= many people were killed).
All risk to human life should be avoided.
He risked his life to save his daughter from the fire.
The operation saved her life.
My grandfather lost his life (= was killed) in the war.
The bombing claimed the lives of (= killed) thousands of people.
Hundreds of lives were threatened when the building collapsed.
Attempts have been made on his life (= people have tried to kill him).

senses.definition: living things mate/​breed/​reproduce/​feed (on something)

examples.x: plant/animal/insect life
Plastic is a threat to marine life.
Nuclear war could mean the end of life on earth.
Is there intelligent life on other planets?
There was no sign of life in the abandoned village.

senses.definition: the period between somebody’s birth and their death; a part of this period

examples.x: He's lived here all his life.
I've lived in England for most of my life.
somebody's whole/entire life
We have known each other our whole lives.
He will spend the rest of his life (= until he dies) in prison.
to have a long/short life
to devote/dedicate your life to something
She's had some interesting experiences in her life.
I've never in my entire life been so embarrassed.
in early/later life
Brenda took up tennis late in life.
A baby's weight will normally double in the first five months of life.
Throughout her life she was dogged by loneliness.
She had three marriages during her 89-year life.
There's no such thing as a job for life any longer.
She stayed there until the end of her life.
He was sentenced to life imprisonment.

senses.definition: a period of somebody’s life when they are in a particular situation or job

examples.x: She has been an accountant all her working life.
He spent his entire adult life in France.
They were very happy throughout their married life.
During his life in Britain he has never worked.
He met a lot of interesting people during his life as a student.

senses.definition: the period of time when something exists or functions

examples.x: In Italy the average life of a government is eleven months.
There are a few things you can do to extend the life of your carpet.
These machines have a limited life (= they do not function well for very long).
These smaller, lighter phones tend to have a shorter battery life.
The International Stock Exchange started life as a coffee shop.
The building will now have a new life as a museum.

senses.definition: the experience and activities that are typical of all people’s existences

examples.x: the worries of everyday life
Commuting is a part of daily life for many people.
He is young and has little experience of life.
Jill wants to travel and see life for herself.
We have no time just to enjoy life.
Life can be hard.
We bought a dishwasher to make life easier.
Life isn't like in the movies, you know.
It's important to have a purpose in life.
In real life (= when she met him) he wasn't how she had imagined him at all.
Can you imagine life without music?
You can share life events like getting married or becoming a parent.
He just needs a little more life experience.

senses.definition: the activities and experiences that are typical of a particular way of living

examples.x: We just want a normal family life.
Technology is part of modern life.
She enjoyed political life.
His fame was so sudden that he was unprepared for public life.
country/city/island life
How do you find life in Japan?
He eventually got used to life in prison.

senses.definition: a person’s experiences during their life; the activities that form a particular part of a person’s life

examples.x: to have/live/lead a… life
He has had a good life.
She lived a quiet life in the countryside.
Many of these children have led very sheltered lives (= they have not had many different experiences).
a hard/an easy life
Her daily life involved meeting lots of people.
My day-to-day life is not very exciting.
Meeting Penny changed my life.
to affect/improve somebody's life
They emigrated to start a new life in Canada.
He doesn't like to talk about his private life.
She has a full social life.
They lead a life of luxury.
I don't want people like that in my life.

senses.definition: the quality of being active and exciting

examples.x: This is a great holiday resort that is full of life.
We need to inject some new life into this project.

senses.definition: the punishment of being sent to prison for life or a very long period of time; life imprisonment

examples.x: The judge gave him life.
She is doing life for murder.

senses.definition: a living model or a real object or scene that people draw or paint

examples.x: She had lessons in drawing from life.
a life class (= one in which art students draw a naked man or woman)

senses.definition: a story of somebody’s life

examples.x: She wrote a life of Mozart.

senses.definition: one of a set number of chances before a player is out of a game

examples.x: He's lost two lives, so he's only got one left.

senses.definition: to give information to somebody by speaking or writing Say

examples.x: He told the news to everybody he saw.
He told everybody he saw the news.
Did she tell you her name?
What did I tell you? (= you should have listened to my advice)
‘Come closer,’ she said, ‘I want to tell you something’.
Why wasn't I told about the accident?
They’ve told us (that) they’re not coming.
I told him straight (= in a direct way) that I wasn't voting for him.
He later told the court that he had returned the money.
I kept telling myself (that) everything was OK.
Are you telling me you didn't have any help with this? (= I don't believe what you have said)
Tell me where you live.
‘I'm ready to go now,’ he told her.
'We hope that there will be some progress,' he told reporters.

senses.definition: to give information about something

examples.x: The advertisement told us very little about the product.
This gauge tells you how much fuel you have left.
The sound of his breathing told her (that) he was asleep.

senses.definition: to express something in words

examples.x: to tell stories/jokes/lies
Are you sure you're telling the truth?
I can't tell you how happy I am.
We'd go fishing and she'd tell me stories.
All of them had an interesting story to tell.

senses.definition: to let somebody know a secret

examples.x: Promise you won't tell.
‘Who are you going out with tonight?’ ‘That would be telling!’ (= it's a secret)

senses.definition: to order or advise somebody to do something order

examples.x: He was told to sit down and wait.
There was a sign telling motorists to slow down.
I kept telling myself to keep calm.
I specifically told you to be here on time.
Do what I tell you.
Children must do as they're told.
Don't tell me what to do!
The doctor told me (that) I should eat less fat.

senses.definition: to know, see or judge something correctly

examples.x: I think he's happy. It's hard to tell.
As far as I can tell, she's enjoying the course.
‘That's not an original.’ ‘How can you tell?’
I could tell (that) he was angry from his expression.
The only way to tell if you like something is by trying it.
It's too early to tell how popular this service will be.
It's impossible to tell exactly where the problem is.

senses.definition: to recognize the difference between one thing or person and another

examples.x: It was hard to tell the difference between the two versions.
Can you tell Tom from his twin brother?
Can you tell this copy from the original?
It's difficult to tell them apart.
The kittens look exactly alike—how can you tell which is which?
I couldn't tell who was meant to be the chairman.

senses.definition: to have an effect on somebody/something, especially a bad one

examples.x: The strain was beginning to tell on the rescue team.

senses.definition: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it knows

examples.x: No one knows the answer.
I need to know your name.
The truth about what happened is not yet known.
All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).
I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.
We know from experience that turning a hobby into a business is not easy.
I know for a fact (that) he didn't go to the party.
‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’
‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’
‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’
As you know, Emma and I are old friends.
‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)
‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).
It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.
I knew where he was hiding.
No one knows for sure who did it.
You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?
I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.
I know next to nothing (= know almost nothing) about opera.
I know of someone who can help us.
‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’
Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?
We know her to be honest.
Strobe lights are known to cause seizures.

senses.definition: to realize, understand or be aware of something

examples.x: As soon as I walked in the room I knew (that) something was wrong.
She knew she was dying.
‘Martin was lying all the time.’ ‘I should have known.’
I knew perfectly well what she meant.
I know exactly how you feel.
This case is hopeless and he knows it (= although he will not admit it).

senses.definition: to feel certain about something knew

examples.x: He knew (that) he could trust her.
I know it's here somewhere!
I know things will turn out all right.
I don't know that I can finish it by next week.
I just knew that it was something I wanted to do.
‘You were right—someone's been spreading rumours about you.’ ‘I knew it!’
‘She's the worst player in the team.’ ‘Oh, I don't know (= I am not sure that I agree)—she played well yesterday.’

senses.definition: to be familiar with a person, place, thing, etc.

examples.x: I've known David for 20 years.
Do you two know each other (= have you met before)?
She was a secretary when I first knew her.
She's very nice when you get to know her.
Knowing Ben, we could be waiting a long time (= it is typical of him to be late).
This man is known to the police (= as a criminal).
I don’t know anyone in Oxford.
I know Paris well.
Do you know the play (= have you seen or read it before)?
How many of your neighbours do you know by name?
The new rules could mean the end of football as we know it (= in the form that we are familiar with).

senses.definition: to have learned a skill or language and be able to use it

examples.x: Do you know any Japanese?
Do you know how to use spreadsheets?

senses.definition: to think that somebody/something is a particular type of person or thing or has particular characteristics

examples.x: He has become widely known as an expert in child psychology.
It's known as the most dangerous part of the city.
She is best known for her work on the human brain.
He is internationally known for his work with vaccines.
He's known to be an outstanding physicist.

senses.definition: to give somebody/something a particular name or title

examples.x: Iran was formerly known as Persia.
The H5N1 virus is more commonly known as bird flu.
Peter Wilson, also known as ‘The Tiger’

examples.cf: be known as somebody/something to somebody
examples.x: He was known as Bonzo to his friends.
The country was not yet known by the name of England.

senses.definition: to be able to recognize somebody/something identify

examples.x: I couldn't see who was speaking, but I knew the voice.
She knows a bargain when she sees one.

senses.definition: to understand the difference between one person or thing and another

examples.x: I hope we have taught our children to know right from wrong.

senses.definition: to have seen, heard or experienced something

examples.x: I’ve never known it (to) snow in July before.
He has been known to spend all morning in the bathroom.

senses.definition: to have personal experience of something

examples.x: He has known both poverty and wealth.
She may be successful now, but she has known what it is like to be poor.
She thought she would never know the joy of seeing a child grow up in her care.

senses.definition: having good luck

examples.x: His friend was killed and he knows he is lucky to be alive.
She was lucky enough to be chosen for the team.
You were lucky (that) you spotted the danger in time.
In terms of my career I feel incredibly lucky.
You can think yourself lucky you didn't get mugged.
She counted herself lucky that she still had a job.
Mark is one of the lucky ones—he at least has somewhere to sleep.
the lucky winners
He was among the lucky ones who escaped with only minor injuries.

senses.definition: being the result of good luck

examples.x: It was lucky for us that we were able to go.
Lucky for her, a police car was passing.
It is lucky (that) neither was killed in the accident.
That was the luckiest escape of my life.
a lucky guess
A lucky find on the edge of the Cotswolds is helping archaeologists discover what life was like in Roman Britain.
I had a lucky break when I left school getting a job on local radio.

senses.definition: bringing good luck

examples.x: a lucky charm
The team thinks of me as their lucky mascot.
